Problem:
Consider the complex function \\(z(t) = e^{i\omega t}\\) where \\(\omega\\) is a fixed frequency. The effect of an integral transformation \\(T[f](s) = \int_0^\infty e^{-st}f(t) dt\\) is examined over this function, both with and without additional transformations.

If we apply a damping factor by transforming \\(z(t)\\) to \\(z(t)e^{-\gamma t}\\), where \\(\gamma >0\\) is a damping coefficient, and then compute \\(T[z](s)\\), will the transformation result depend only on the added \\(\gamma\\) and not on \\(s\\) or \\(\omega\\)?
Explanation: The new transformation \\(T[z](s) = \int_0^\infty e^{-st} e^{i\omega t} e^{-\gamma t} dt = \int_0^\infty e^{-(s+\gamma)t} e^{i\omega t} dt = \frac{1}{s+\gamma - i\omega}\\) shows that the result depends on \\(\gamma\\), as well as \\(s\\) and \\(\omega\\). Thus, all three parameters shape the transformation outcome.
